conclusion: The area under the acceleration-time graph represents the change in velocity.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the acceleration is +2 m/s².
Velocity increases from t = 0 to t = 1 second.
From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, acceleration decreases linearly from +2 m/s² to 0 m/s².
Velocity continues to increase but at a decreasing rate from t = 1 to t = 2 seconds.
At t = 2 seconds, the acceleration becomes zero.
Velocity is no longer increasing at t = 2 seconds.
From t = 2 to t = 3 seconds, the acceleration is negative.
Velocity decreases from t = 2 to t = 3 seconds.
From t = 3 to t = 4 seconds, the acceleration remains negative.
Velocity continues to decrease from t = 3 to t = 4 seconds.
Velocity reaches its maximum when acceleration changes from positive to zero at t = 2 seconds.
The object's velocity is at its maximum at t = 2 seconds.
